docs.lead_paragraph: A few minutes after Gary Sheffield said yesterday that Major League Baseball should strongly penalize fans who interfere with players or infringe on their safety, the Boston Red Sox announced punishments for two fans who were involved in an incident with Sheffield at Fenway Park last Thursday. The Red Sox said they would revoke the season tickets of Chris House, who reached over the three-foot-high fence in right field and touched Sheffield as he was trying to field a ball. Team officials also said that a second fan, who dumped beer on Sheffield, would not be permitted to buy tickets this season.

docs.lead_paragraph: As they plotted their strategy for beating the Yankees last November, Boston Red Sox officials visited Curt Schilling at his home in Arizona and persuaded Schilling to accept a trade from the Diamondbacks. A year later, Schilling is a World Series hero for Boston, and he is doing the recruiting. The free agent right-hander Carl Pavano, who will meet with the Yankees soon, spent two hours at Schilling's home in Medfield, Mass., yesterday. With Schilling resting after ankle surgery last week, Pavano made the 20-mile trip from Boston for lunch. He also met at Fenway Park with General Manager Theo Epstein and Manager Terry Francona.

docs.lead_paragraph: A handful of Red Sox players were watching the Yankees begin their frenetic ninth inning against the Kansas City Royals this afternoon, but Kevin Millar refused even to glance at the two big-screen televisions in the middle of the clubhouse at Fenway Park. Millar was already weary of hearing and reading about the Yankees, so he did not need to see them, too. Actually, Millar was tired of hearing and reading about how the Red Sox are fading in their pursuit of the Yankees again. Same story, different season. Millar said he rarely read newspapers, barely listened to sports radio and only occasionally saw television reports, but he was exposed to enough words, voices and pictures to annoy him.

''Someone who can take a look at a player and tell you whether he can play or not is invaluable,'' said Epstein, who became the youngest general manager in baseball history when he was hired on Monday. ''We just got one.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Johnny Kucks had two strikes against a legend. One ball and two strikes, Ted Williams at the plate in Yankee Stadium, 6 feet 3 inches and bigger than life. He stood in the left-handed batter's box, bent slightly at the waist, his stance closed just a bit, his eyes staring at Kucks, all-seeing, all-knowing. Kucks was 21 years old, in his rookie season for the Yankees in 1955, and he was intimidated. ''You knew what kind of hitter he was,'' Kucks recalled yesterday, remembering each pitch of the at-bat. He needed one more strike, and spun a curveball, which might have surprised Williams, because Kucks relied on a sinkerball and his curveball was not that good. Kucks thought it went over the plate, and Williams took it. Ball two, the umpire said. ''He got a lot of calls, because if he took a pitch, the umpires gave it to him because his eye was so good,'' Kucks said.

''All I have to do is build up my throwing, practice enough in the bullpen and probably throw B.P. or a simulated game. That's going to be it.'' docs.lead_paragraph: Nomar Garciaparra had wrist surgery yesterday at UMass Memorial Health Care in Worcester, an opening day operation that could deprive the Boston Red Sox of their All-Star shortstop and a two-time American League batting champion for half the season. And there is no assurance that his right wrist -- which had a split tendon surrounded by an inflamed sheath -- will ever be as strong as it was before the injury.
